questions.text: A 55-year-old male underwent cardiopulmonary bypass surgery. In post op ICU resident observes low urine output. Which of the following mechanisms is NOT responsible for this finding?
questions.solution:
Longer duration of cardiopulmonary bypass surgery is a risk factor for development of AKI.

Option A and B - due to passage of blood in extracorporeal circuits, leucocyte activation occurs and may result in hemolysis. Hemoglobin being toxic to the tubules may cause acute tubular necrosis or pigment nephropathy.

Option C- due to sustained hypoperfusion, prerenal AKI can occur.

Option D - interstitial damage is unlikely and usually occurs in following cases:

  • Allergic (PCN, PPIs, NSAIDs, Rifampin, etc.)
  • Infection (severe pyelonephritis, Legionella, sepsis)
  • Infiltration (lymphoma, leukemia)
  • Inflammatory (Sjogren's, tubulointerstitial nephritis, uveitis), sepsis.

Topic: Acute kidney Injury

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Chapter: 310, Page number. 2299.

choices.text: Non invasive positive pressure ventilation with a tight mask
HNFO (high flow nasal oxygen) with air humidifier

questions.text: A 55-year-old male known case of hypertension, diabetes smoker since 30 years was brought to opd in a drowsy state but arousable. Vitals - Bp - 80/60, PR - 112/min, RR - 16/min. ABG was done. Ph 7.25, PCO2 - 55, pO2 - 65, hco3 - 29, lactate 2.8. What is the best line of management?
questions.solution:
This is a case of type 2 respiratory failure probably secondary to COPD as the patient is a chronic smoker. Now he is in shock probably respiratory cause and infective etiology.

  • Noninvasive positive-pressure ventilation with a tight-fitting facial or nasal mask, with avoidance of endotracheal intubation, may stabilize these patients in certain circumstances like exacerbations of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. But this patient is not an ideal candidate for NIV due to hemodynamic instability and increased risk of aspiration (as he is drowsy)

CONTRAINDICATIONS OF NIPPV:

  • hemodynamic instability
  • inability to protect the airway
  • respiratory arrest
  • significant airway secretions
  • significant aspiration risk

Topic: TYPE- II Respiratory Failure

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Chapter: 300, Page number. 2221.

choices.text: i-b, ii-a, iii - d, iv - c

questions.text: Match the correct pair regarding antibiotics and their mechanism of kidney injury.
questions.solution:
i) vancomycin -Vancomycin may be associated with AKI from tubular injury, particularly when trough levels are high and when used in combination with other nephrotoxic antibiotics. Vancomycin can also crystalize in tubules and cause intratubular obstruction.

ii) aminoglycoside - Aminoglycosides and amphotericin B both cause tubular necrosis. Non-oliguric AKI (i.e., with a urine volume >400 mL/day) accompanies 10-30% of courses of aminoglycoside antibiotics, even when plasma levels are in the therapeutic range. AKI typically manifests after 5-7 days of therapy and can present even after the drug has been discontinued. Hypomagnesemia is a common finding.

iii) amphotericin b -Amphotericin B causes renal vasoconstriction as well as direct tubular toxicity mediated by reactive oxygen species. Nephrotoxicity from amphotericin B is dose and duration dependent. Clinical features of amphotericin B nephrotoxicity include polyuria, hypomagnesemia, hypocalcemia, and non-gap metabolic acidosis.

Option D - cephalosporins -penicillin's, cephalosporins, quinolones, sulphonamides, and Rifampin can cause acute interstitial nephritis

Topic: Mechanism of Acute Kidney Injury

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Chapter: 310, Page number 2300.

questions.text: Which of the following is a less likely cause for nephrotic range proteinuria?
questions.solution:
Causes of nephrotic range proteinuria:

  • Diabetes
  • Amyloidosis
  • Minimal change disease
  • FSGS
  • Membranous glomerulopathy
  • IgA nephropathy

Topic: Nephrotic range Proteinuria

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Chapter: 52, Page number 336

choices.text: ACE inhibitors are preferred for management of hypertension in this patient
Renal angiography with stent placement has superior results as compared to medical therapy for controlling BP and preserving kidney function

questions.text: A 50-year female came with complaints of headache. Bp is 200/120. On examination carotid bruit is present. USG shows aplasia of left kidney and increased velocity in the right renal artery. Which of the following statements is true?
questions.solution:
This is a case of renovascular hypertension in a patient with single kidney.

Option a - in general ACE inhibitors and ARBs are preferred to treat renovascular hypertension except in the cases where the patient has bilateral renal artery stenosis or single kidney. This patient has aplasia of one kidney, hence in her if RAAS blocking drugs are given they will further deteriorate her renal function and bp control.

Option b - renal arteriography with stent placement in patients with arteriosclerotic renal artery stenosis offers no advantages over medical therapy in controlling blood pressure, reducing cardiovascular events and mortality, or preserving kidney function.

Topic: Renal artery stenosis

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Chapter: 277, Page number. 2078.

choices.text: 3% NACL is contraindicated in hypervolemic hyponatremia
Inhibitors of arginine vasopressin action are given in hypovolemic hyponatremia
Cortisol or thyroxine replacement may help in euvolemic hyponatremia

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding management of hyponatremia?
questions.solution:
Option a - Infusion of hypertonic saline is absolutely contraindicated in hypervolemic hyponatremia because it further increases total body sodium and water, worsens the edema, and may precipitate cardiovascular decompensation.

Option b - hypovolemic hyponatremia, fluid restriction and inhibitors of AVP action are absolutely contraindicated because they aggrevate the hypovolemia and could precipitate hemodynamic collapse.

Option c - In euvolemic hyponatremia, the treatment of choice depends on the cause. If it is a deficiency in cortisol or thyroxine, gradual replacement usually suffices to eliminate all signs and symptoms, including the hyponatremia. In SIADH, the excess body water should be eliminated.

Topic: Hyponatremia

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Chapter: 381, Page number. 2925.

choices.text: Acid base disorder doesn't exist, it's a simple potassium deficiency due to GI loss which needs IV correction

questions.text: An alcoholic came to opd with c/o 10 episodes of vomiting since 2 days, weakness. His ABG shows pH 7.4, bicarbonate - 24 mmol/L, paCO2 - 40 mmHg. Serum electrolytes are Na - 135, Cl-80, k-2.8. What is the acid base disorder in this patient?
questions.solution:
• When ever we see an ABG ensuring the ph, bicarbonate and paCO2 as normal alone is not sufficient, we need to take look at the serum electrolytes also so as to calculate Anion gap. The reason is, if there is a mixed alkalosis and acidosis ph will be neutralized towards normalcy.
  • Although these blood gases are normal, the AG is elevated at 30 mmol/L, indicating a mixed metabolic alkalosis and metabolic acidosis is present.
  • A mixture of high-gap acidosis and metabolic alkalosis is recognized easily by comparing the differences (Δ values) in the normal to prevailing patient values. In this example, the ΔHCO3 − is 0 (25 − 25 mmol/L), but the ΔAG is 20 (30 - 10 mmol/L). Therefore, 20 mmol/L is unaccounted for in the Δ/Δ value (ΔAG to ΔHCO3)
  • Excessive vomiting results in loss of stomach acid resulting in metabolic alkalosis. This patient also has alcoholic ketosis, i.e. Metabolic acidosis.

Topic: Acid-Base Balance disorder

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Chapter: 55, Page number. 361.

choices.text: Subclavian vein is the most preferred site of catheter insertion
" Fistula first " initiative is to be followed
Brescia-Cimino fistula, in which the cephalic vein is anastomised end-to-side to the radial artery

questions.text: A 55-year male came with complaints of reduced urine output, USG shows impaired corticomedullary differentiation, thinned out cortex bilaterally and contracted kidneys on both sides. Urine output per day is <400ml. Which of the following statements is false regarding the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The usg findings suggest that it's a chronic kidney disease.

Absolute Indications for dialysis in CKD:

  • Uremic pericarditis or pleuritis.
  • Uremic encephalopathy

Other Clear indications for initiation of renal replacement therapy for patients with CKD include

  • anorexia and nausea not attributable to reversible causes such as peptic ulcer disease
  • evidence of malnutrition
  • fluid and electrolyte abnormalities, principally hyperkalemia or ECFV overload, that are refractory to other measures.

Few important points about dialysis access:

  • FISTULA FIRST INITIATIVE - fistula is the preferred mode of access as there is less infection and failure rate.
  • if fistula fails AV graft is used.
  • if graft also fails tunnelled catheters are used. They are also called as the last lifeline in dialysis.
  • most important complication of arteriovenous grafts is intimal hyperplasia and thrombosis of the graft resulting in graft failure.
  • grafts and catheters are associated with much higher rates of infection than fistulas
  • avoid placement of catheters into the subclavian veins; while flow rates are usually excellent, subclavian stenosis is a frequent complication and, if present, will likely prohibit permanent vascular access (i.e., a fistula or graft) in the ipsilateral extremity
  • Infection rates may be higher with femoral catheters.

Topic: Chronic kidney disease > Access

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Chapter:312, Page number 2322

questions.text: Which of the following may result in adynamic bone disease in CKD patients except?
questions.solution:
Adynamic bone disease is increasing in prevalence, especially among diabetics and older patients. It is characterized by reduced bone volume and mineralization and may result from excessive suppression of PTH production, chronic inflammation, or both. Suppression of PTH can result from the use of vitamin D preparations or from excessive calcium exposure in the form of calcium-containing phosphate binders or high-calcium dialysis solutions.

TUMORAL CALCINOSIS

It is a part of the spectrum of adynamic bone disease. calcium will precipitate in the soft tissues into large concretions termed tumoral calcinosis

CALCIPHYLAXIS

  • Calciphylaxis is heralded by painful livedo reticularis and subcutaneous nodules that advance to patches of ischemic necrosis, especially on the legs, thighs, abdomen, and breasts.
  • Vascular occlusion due to extensive vascular and soft tissue calcification.
  • It is associated with advanced hyperparathyroidism.
  • sometimes when warfarin is used in dialysis there is decrease the vitamin K-dependent activation of matrix GLA protein. This latter protein is important in preventing vascular calcification. Thus, warfarin treatment is considered a risk factor for calciphylaxis,

BROWN TUMORS:

  • Hyperparathyroidism stimulates bone turnover and leads to osteitis fibrosa cystica
  • bone marrow fibrosis, and, in advanced stages, the formation of bone cysts, sometimes with hemorrhagic elements so that they appear brown in colour; hence, the term brown tumor.

Topic: Chronic kidney disease > complication

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Chapter: 311, Page number. 2314.

Topic: ARDS

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Chapter: 301, Page number. 2229.

questions.text: An ICU patient is in hypotension. Central venous pressure monitoring is being done, shows lower pressures. Peripheral vascular resistance is reduced. What is this condition?
questions.solution:
Option b - septic shock is a type of distributive shock. the primary physiologic disturbance is a reduction in SVR. It is unique among the types of shock in that there is a compensatory increase in CO.

Option c - Obstructive shock - Specific processes that can impede venous return to the heart and reduce CO include tension pneumothorax, cardiac tamponade, and restrictive pericarditis. Similarly processes that obstruct cardiac outflow, such as pulmonary embolism, venous air embolism, fat embolism (right heart), or aortic dissection (left heart), are included in this shock type category.

[image: CVP monitoring catheter]

Topic: Shock

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Chapter: 303, Page number. 2236.

choices.text: Norepinephrine is recommended as the first-choice vasopressor
Dopamine should be used with the intent of reducing the norepinephrine dose
The use of dopamine should be avoided except in specific situations like risk of tachyarrhythmia or relative bradycardia
Dobutamine use is suggested when patients show persistent evidence of hypoperfusion despite adequate fluid loading and use of vasopressors

questions.text: A 70-year-old male HIV positive is admitted for community acquired pneumonia. The next day he developed fluid resuscitation resistant hypotension. Which of the following statements is false regarding the management of blood pressure?
questions.solution:
Option a - Norepinephrine is recommended as the first-choice vasopressor.

Option b - Vasopressin should be used with the intent of reducing the norepinephrine dose.

Option c - The use of dopamine should be avoided except in specific situations-e.g., in those patients at highest risk of tachyarrhythmias or relative bradycardia.

Option d - Dobutamine use is suggested when patients show persistent evidence of hypoperfusion despite adequate fluid loading and use of vasopressors.

Topic: Vasopressors and Inotropes

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Chapter: 304, Page number 2247.

choices.text: Sudden unexpected death attributed to cardiac arrest, which if witnessed occurs within 1 h of symptom onset
Abrupt cessation of cardiac function resulting in loss of effective circulation that may be reversible by prompt emergency medical intervention but will lead to death in its absence
Sudden loss of effective circulation due to cardiac and/or peripheral vascular factors that may reverse spontaneously or require interventions
Chronic and progressive condition where the heart muscle is unable to pump enough blood through the body to meet the body's need for blood and oxygen

questions.text: What do you mean by cardiovascular collapse?
questions.solution:
Option d is definition of heart failure - chronic and progressive condition where the heart muscle is unable to pump enough blood through the body to meet the body's need for blood and oxygen.

Topic: Cardiovascular collapse

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Chapter: 4, Page number. 2258.

choices.text: Deep grey matter is commonly involved
Burst-suppression pattern of myoclonic status epilepticus on EEG is associated with poor prognosis
Targeted temperature management to 31 or 35° is approved in cardiac arrest patients

questions.text: A 54-year-old male patient admitted in ICU had a sudden cardiac arrest however the patient was revived with CPR (return of spontaneous circulation). Patient failed to regain consciousness but is vitally stable with supports. Brain imaging and EEG was done, image attached. Which of the following statements is false?
questions.solution:
This is a case of hypoxic ischemic brain injury.

Option a - Brain imaging shows diffusion restriction in deep grey nuclei which is a common feature of HIE.

Option b - EEG shows burst-suppression pattern of myoclonic status epilepticus on EEG is associated with a low likelihood of good functional outcome.

Option c - Current guidelines recommend TTM (targeted temperature monitoring) for cardiac arrest patients who have no meaningful response to verbal commands after return of spontaneous circulation, with temperature maintained constant between 32 and 36°C for at least 24 h

Topic: Hypoxic ischemic brain injury

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Chapter: 307, Page number. 2272

questions.text: A 22-year male presented to casualty with complaints of fever, severe headache and neck pain. Antibiotics and other supportive medication have been started. Patients relative describes development of generalized clonic tonic movements since 10 minutes. What is the initial management?
questions.solution:
• The most common causes of GCSE are anticonvulsant withdrawal or noncompliance, metabolic disturbances, drug toxicity, CNS infection, CNS tumors, refractory epilepsy, and head trauma.
  • uninterrupted seizures for more than 5 minutes duration up to 30 minutes is called impending or early status epilepticus (SE) . From 30 minutes to 48 hours is called established and early refractory status epilepticus. If persistent beyond 48 hr is called late refractory status epilepticus.

Option A, B- phenytoin, levetiracetam or valproic acid is usually given after benzodiazepines.

Option c-the initial 5 - 30 minutes of SE is considered as impending and early SE which is treated with IV benzodiazepines like midazolam, lorazepam, clonazepam.

Option d - lacosamide can be given in established SE with focal seizures and no response with IV Benzodiazepines and IV antiseizure medication like phenytoin/levetiracetam /valproate.

Topic: Status epilepticus.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Chapter: 425, Page number. 3322.

questions.text: A 45-year male comes to OPD with productive cough and fever, on auscultation there are expiratory fine crackles in the left basal region. Drug history tells that patient is on pyridostigmine since 5 years and a surgical scar on his neck. Which of the following antibiotics can be prescribed in this patient?
questions.solution:
• The above patient has myasthenia gravis, the scar is due to thymectomy.

Number of drugs interact with myasthenia gravis and exacerbate the weakness.

  • macrolides, fluoroquinolones and aminoglycosides must be avoided.

Topic: Drug causing Myasthenia Gravis.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Chapter: 448, Page number. 3516.

choices.text: i- a, ii - c, iii - d, iv - b
i-d, ii - b, iii - c, iv - a
i - c, ii - a, iii- b, iv - d
i - b, ii - d, iii - a, iv - c

questions.text: Management of various types of headaches - match the correct pair.
questions.solution:
SUNCT /SUNA -

  • Abortive therapy - IV Lidocaine
  • Preventive therapy - lamotrigine

HEMICRANIA CONTINUA

  • Drug of choice - indomethacin, other NSAIDs appear to be of little or no benefit. The IM injection of 100 mg of indomethacin has been proposed as a diagnostic tool.
  • Topiramate
  • nVNS (non-invasive vagal nerve stimulation)
  • Occipital nerve stimulation

CLUSTER HEADACHE

  • abortive treatment - 100% oxygen at 10-12 L/min for 15-20 min (high flow and high oxygen content are important) and Sumatriptan 6 mg SC.
  • Prevention - (a) short term prevention - prednisolone, melatonin (b) long-term prevention- verapamil, melatonin, lithium

MIGRAINE

  • Prevention
    1. Beta blockers - propranolol, metoprolol
    2. Anti-depressants - amitryptyline
    3. Anti convulsants - topiramate, valproate
    4. Serotonergic drugs - pizotifen
    5. CGRP antagonists - Eptinezumab, Erenumab, Fremanezumab, Galcanezumab, Rimegepant
  • Abortive therapy - nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs; 5-HT1B/1D

receptor agonists-triptans; CGRP receptor antagonists-gepants; 5-HT1F receptor agonists-ditans; and dopamine receptor antagonists.

Topic: Headache

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Chapter: 430, Page number. 3367.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male who is a known case of hypertension and asthma came with complaints of involuntary rhythmic oscillations of both hands since 6 months. There are similar cases in the family. Frequency of oscillation is 6-10 Hz; tremor is improved by alcohol intake. It increases while performing work. What is the treatment?
questions.solution:
This is a case of benign essential tremors.

Standard drugs used in essential tremors are beta blockers or primidone. As he is asthmatic, beta blockers cannot be given in him, primidone would be the choice.

IMPORTANT POINTS REGARDING ESSENTIAL TREMORS:

  • high-frequency tremor - 6-10 Hz
  • Increased prevalence among 70 plus age
  • Seen in 5% of entire population
  • They manifest as postural or action tremors
  • The tremor is characteristically improved by alcohol and worsened by stress
  • large handwriting
  • Parkinsons tremor can usually be differentiated from ET because the former stops at the onset of a voluntary action but ET persists throughout the action.
  • Inheritance - autosomal dominant
  • Tremor pacemaker is - cerebellum and inferior olives
  • Beta blockers and primidone are the standard drug therapies for ET. Hand tremor tends to be most improved, while head tremor is often refractory
  • focal ultrasound (FUS) over the ventro-intermediate (VIM) nucleus of the thalamus is useful to treat ET.

Topic: Essential Tremors

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Chapter: 436, Page number. 3401.

choices.text: The lack of noticeable improvement following a course of IV Ig or PLEX is an indication to treat with the alternate treatment
Occasionally patients who are treated early in the course of GBS with IVIG may improve, and then relapse within a month, PLEX must be tried in them
High dose IV glucocorticoids in patients who are unable to afford IVIG has been tried but found not to be useful

questions.text: A 43-year-old male came with complaints of weakness in both the legs since yesterday associated with tingling sensation, and now notices that his facial muscles are not moving and weakness progressed to hands also. He is able to hold urine. On examination lower limb power is 2/5 and absent reflexes, sensation preserved. What is true regarding the treatment of his condition?
questions.solution:
Option a - The lack of noticeable improvement following a course of IVIg or PLEX is not an indication to treat with the alternate treatment.

Option b - occasional patients who are treated early in the course of GBS and improve, who then relapse within a month. Brief retreatment with the original therapy is usually effective in such cases.

Option c - Glucocorticoids have not been found to be effective in GBS.

TREATMENT OF GBS:

  • ~2 weeks after the first motor symptoms, it is not known whether immunotherapy is still effective
  • If the patient has already reached the plateau stage then treatment probably is no longer indicated unless he has severe motor deficit and ongoing immunological damage cannot be ruled out.
  • IVIG and PLEX are equally effective.
  • GBS autoantibodies are neutralized by anti-idiotypic antibodies in IVIG
  • The lack of noticeable improvement following a course of IVIg or PLEX is not an indication to treat with the alternate treatment
  • occasional patients who are treated early in the course of GBS and improve, who then relapse within a month. Brief retreatment with the original therapy is usually effective in such cases
  • Glucocorticoids have not been found to be effective in GBS.
  • ~30% of patients with GBS require ventilatory assistance,

Topic: Guillain Barre syndrome

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Chapter: 447, Page number. 3504.

questions.text: A 35-year female came with complaints of weakness of the ipsilateral shoulder and arm followed by weakness of the ipsilateral leg, then the contralateral leg, and finally the contralateral arm. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option a - Central Cord Syndrome - This syndrome results from selective damage to the cells and crossing spinothalamic tracts surrounding the central canal. In the cervical cord, the central cord syndrome produces arm weakness out of proportion to leg weakness and a "dissociated" sensory loss, meaning loss of pain and temperature sensations over the shoulders, lower neck, and upper trunk (cape distribution), in contrast to preservation of light touch, joint position, and vibration sense in these regions.

Spinal trauma, syringomyelia, and intrinsic cord tumors are the main causes.

Option b - Foramen Magnum Syndrome - Lesions in this area interrupt decussating pyramidal tract fibers destined for the legs, which cross caudal to those of the arms, resulting in weakness of the legs (crural paresis).

Compressive lesions near the foramen magnum may produce weakness of the ipsilateral shoulder and arm followed by weakness of the ipsilateral leg, then the contralateral leg, and finally the contralateral arm, an "around-the-clock" pattern.

Option c - Anterior Spinal Artery Syndrome - spares the posterior columns. All spinal cord functions-motor, sensory, and autonomic-are lost below the level of the lesion, with the striking exception of retained vibration and position sensation.

Option d - Cervical Cord Lesions -

  • Upper cervical cord lesions produce quadriplegia and weakness of the diaphragm.
  • The uppermost level of weakness and reflex loss with lesions at C5-C6 is in the biceps; at C7, in finger and wrist extensors and triceps; and at C8, finger and wrist flexion.
  • Horner's syndrome can occur at any level.

Topic: Spinal cord syndrome

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Chapter: 442, Page number. 3446.

questions.text: A 50-year woman came with complaints of early morning cramping in the bed, involuntary twitching of hand muscles. Attender also complaints of inappropriate and excess crying as well as laughing.On examination, thenar eminence is flat, jerks are exaggerated. Which of the following treatments is least useful?
questions.solution:
This is a case of ALS.

Clues to the diagnosis -

  • exaggerated jerks suggest involvement of upper motor neuron.
  • atrophy of thenar eminence and complaint of fasciculations suggest lower motor neuron involvement.
  • inappropriate excess laughing and crying is called pseudobulbar effect which is due to involvement of corticobulbar tract.
  • involvement of both UMN (both corticospinal and corticobulbar tracts) and LMN is suggestive of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.

TREATMENT FOR ALS:

  • riluzole - reduce excitotoxicity by diminishing glutamate release
  • edavarone - antioxidant
  • phenylbutyrate and taurorsodiol - improves function in mitochondria and the endoplasmic reticulum.
  • benfotiamine - it is a synthetic variant of vitamin B1, no data regarding its

benefits in ALS.

Topic: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Chapter: 437, Page number 3415.

choices.text: Transformation rate from relapsing MS to secondary progressing MS is 1% per year
During pregnancy the frequency of attacks increase
Exercise-induced weakness is a characteristic symptom of MS

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding multiple sclerosis?
questions.solution:
Option a - transformation rate from relapsing MS to secondary progressing MS is 1% per year

Option b - fewer attacks than expected during gestation (especially in the last trimester), but more attacks than expected in the first 3 months postpartum are seen

Option c - Exercise-induced weakness is a characteristic symptom of MS

Topic: Multiple sclerosis

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Chapter: 427, Page number 3338

choices.text: Maltese cross appearance on polarised microscopy

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding Fabry's disease?
questions.solution:
FABRYS DISEASE:

  • X-linked inborn error of globotriaosylcera-mide metabolism secondary to deficient lysosomal a-galactosidase A.
  • Classically, Fabry's disease presents in childhood in males with acroparesthesias, angiokeratoma, cornea verticillate, and hypo hidrosis.
  • Over time, male patients develop cardiomyopathy, cerebrovascular disease, and renal injury, with an average age of death around 50 years of age.
  • zebra bodies are seen on electron microscopy.
  • Maltese cross appearance seen on polarized microscopy.

(image shows zebra bodies on electron microscopy)

Topic: Fabry's disease

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Chapter: 418, Page number. 3258

choices.text: Bilateral nephroureterectomy needs to be done later
Anemia is very mild disproportionate to the degree of renal damage

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding ARISTOLOCHIC ACID NEPHROPATHY?
questions.solution:
Important points about aristocholic acid nephropathy:

  • contamination of local grain preparations with the seeds of Aristolochia species
  • renal interstitial fibrosis, paucity of cellular infiltrates
  • bland urine segment, mild proteinuria
  • Anemia may be disproportionately severe relative to the level of kidney dysfunction.
  • upper urinary tract urothelial cancers
  • bilateral nephroureterectomy once a patient has reached ESRD

Topic: Aristolochic Acid Nephropathy

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Chapter: 316, Page number. 2362
